content:
Yes, it's possible to write a program to analyze a set of links scraped from a page and identify the pattern. One way to do this is to use regular expressions to search for patterns in the URLs.

Here's an example Python code that demonstrates how to identify the URL pattern based on a set of links:
```python
import re

# Example set of links
links = [
    'https://example.com/category/page/1',
    'https://example.com/category/page/2',
    'https://example.com/category/page/3',
    'https://example.com/category/page/4',
    'https://example.com/category/page/5'
]

# Try to identify the pattern in the links
patterns = []
for link in links:
    # Define regular expression to extract page number
    regex = r'/page/(\d+)'
    match = re.search(regex, link)
    if match:
        # Extract the page number
        page_number = match.group(1)
        # Replace the page number with a regex placeholder
        pattern = re.sub(regex, r'/page/\d+', link)
        pattern = pattern.replace(page_number, r'\d+')
        # Add the pattern to the list
        patterns.append(pattern)

# Print the identified pattern(s)
if patterns:
    # Remove duplicates
    patterns = list(set(patterns))
    print('Identified pattern(s):')
    for pattern in patterns:
        print(pattern)
else:
    print('No pattern found')
```
In this code, we start by defining a set of example links. We then loop through each link and use regular expressions to try to identify the URL pattern. If a pattern is found, we replace the page number with a regex placeholder (`\d+`) and add the pattern to a list. Finally, we remove duplicates from the list and print the identified pattern(s).

This code is just an example, and you may need to modify it based on the specific URL patterns and page structure of the website you are scraping.
